_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is prepared for the Premier DeBeque Gas Plant located at 4344  V 2/10 Road in DeBeque, Colorado, 81630.  The purpose of this RMP is to strive for the prevention of NGL accidental releases from the facility and to reduce the severity of any release which might occur.

As stipulated to in 29 CFR 1910.119, a process that involves a flammable liquid or gas on site in one location, at or above a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds would require Process Safety Management (PSM).  The Premier DeBeque facility meets the requirements as defined by the US Department of Labor Occupational, Safety, and Health Administration (OSHA) as a PSM facility.  However, the facility is not manned and for the five years prior to the submission of this RMP, the process has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any offsite death, injury, or a response to an environmental receptor.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION / EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The DeBeque Premier Gas Plant is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel and contractors working in the facility, neighbors in the surrounding area, and the environment. This commitment is supported by management as demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, which include, but are not limited to, training and safety in the operation, and maintenance of the plant. The facility implements both administrative and engineering controls to minimize the risk of a release of a flammable substance. 

In addition, while an uncontrolled release is not anticipated, established emergency response policies are designed to minimize impacts on human health and the environment. In the event such a release should occur, the personnel at the plant, in cooperation with local response

agencies, are able to respond, minimize, and/or eliminate any exposure that could occur to protect human health and the environment.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 

The Debeque Premier Gas Plant is owned and operated by Energy Transfer Company, Canyon Pipeline, LLC, (ETC).  The entire operation is contained within the property boundary and no other companies operate on the property. Thus, by definition, the DPGP is a stationary source.  

The primary activity at the Premier Gas Plant is the gathering, handling, and compression of natural gas.  In addition, as part of the facility operation, natural gas liquids (NGL) are separated from the natural gas stream, stored on site, and sold to a petroleum refiner.  Constituents of NGL include the following listed regulated substances: ethane (CAS# 74-84-0), propane (CAS# 74-98-6), Isobutane (CAS# 75-28-5), and Isopentane (CAS# 78-78-4).

There are no regulated toxic substances stored at the plant. Operators are knowledgeable as to the activation of the emergency shutdown, which will limit the exposure of any release to the surrounding public.

WORST CASE AND ALTERATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for each of the constituents have been completed using the Environmental Protection Agency's RMP*Comp, Version 1.07.  The endpoint for the scenario for a vapor cloud explosion type release is 0.2 miles.

Employees visually inspect the plant each day and provide any necessary maintenance, thereby decreasing the possibility of any release to the outside environment. A preventive maintenance program further reduces the possibility of a release equal to the Worst Case or Alternative Release Scenario. 

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The DeBeque Premier Gas Plant has both administrative and engineering controls in place to prevent the accidental release of a regulated substance.  The administrative policies include, but are not limited to, initial training and refresher tra

ining of all personnel, competence tests of all personnel, and a written hazard communication plan and management system.  Engineering controls include, but are not limited to, relief valves, emergency shut off valves, and flow regulators.

In addition, the plant is regulated by many Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standards and Regulations and complies with regulations governed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) including Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Section 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals), Section 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), and Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Section 112 (Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure). The Plant also complies with federal Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Regulations and other state regulations which aim to reduce the potential for a release of chemicals to the environment.

The facility Accident Prevention Program incorporates all of the requirements of Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and EPA's Risk Management Program.  The Accident Prevention Program is used in the identification, evaluation, prevention, or mitigation of chemical releases resulting from a failure in processes, procedures or equipment.

Employees have received comprehensive training. The training program is on-going, and incorporates information for the handling of on-site, listed RMP chemicals. Employees have received training about the process, including operations and maintenance procedures and safe work practices. 

Safe work practices have been developed to ensure safe operations consistent with industry practice and meet regulatory requirements. These practices include lock-out/tag-out, line breaking, confined space entry and hot work permits to ensure the safe operation of the facility and the protection of employees, contractors, and the surrounding area.


 
An incident investigation will be conducted in the event tha

t such a situation occurs. The results of the investigation will be used to enhance the safe operation of the facility.

Audit procedures have been established and are followed to
ensure the continued integrity of the prevention program, and the safety of employees, contractors, and the protection of the surrounding environment. 


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

For the five years prior to the submission of this RMP, the process has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any offsite death, injury, or a response to an environmental receptor.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Debeque Primer Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan, which is in place to protect employees and contract workers, ensure public safety, and to protect the environment. The plan details procedures for contacting responders for mitigation of a release of a regulated substance. The plan addresses aspects of emergency response by outside experts, and includes instructions for communication, first aid, evacuation, accounting for personnel, company and agency notification procedures, and post incident cleanup and decontamination. In addition, the Plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of any emergency response equipment maintained on site, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency protection equipment. Employees receive appropriate training in procedures necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties which includes contacting trained responders. The Emergency Response Plan is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other facilities within the plant. Changes to the plan include informing and/or training affected personnel of the changes.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

At this time,

due to the lack of significant changes to the facility and the accident history, no safety improvements are planned for the facility.  The Plant maintains an ongoing safety training program so that employees and contractors have current information. Any new or modified equipment will be designed with appropriate safety controls and devices.
